text: Code

Roles

Content Creator

Work only in their graft branch.
Never merge back – their content is pulled in by the trunk.
Typical loop:

git checkout my-graft-branch
…working on the content…
make preview
git commit and git push




Trunk Maintainer

Owns the main trunk.
Controls the inventory grafts.yaml and grafts.lock.
Maintains docs/_quart.yaml and site branding.
Run trunk builds, publishing pipelines.
Owns graft lifecycle: graft-new, graft-list, graft-destroy, graft-cleanup-orphans



Template Contributor

Propose and evolve the starter skeletons used for new grafts.
Submit changes via PRs to main; maintainers promote accepted templates into the templates/ folder.

Code






Glossary

Graft: A git branch containing Quarto content that will be mounted into the trunk site.
Trunk: The main branch that controls grafts.yaml, runs builds, and publishes.
Worktree: A checked-out view of a branch living under .grafts/<name>, keeping contributor work isolated.
Export: The rendered output from a graft branch under docs/grafts__/.

title: marimo tutorials
text:
Compose a single Quarto site from branch-scoped worktrees.

Quarto Graft lets contributors build chapters, sections, or full sub-sites in isolated git branches while the trunk assembles everything into one fully searchable Quarto website.


Traditional versioned collaboration forces everyone into main, leading to merge conflicts, shared heavy dependencies, and a single project shape. Quarto Graft flips that model:

Each contributor owns one branch = one self-contained chapter/section with its own language, environment, and runtime.
The trunk never executes contributor code; it only ingests rendered artifacts, keeping main fast and stable.
Broken branches don’t block the site: last-good fallbacks keep content online with visible warnings.





Ready-to-publish Quarto scaffold (navbar, sidebar, favicon, footer, search, GitHub links).
Branch-grafting build system using git worktrees + uv and automatic navigation updates.
Clean contributor workflow: no cross-branch conflicts or shared dependency coupling; full local preview per branch.
Failure handling: last-good fallbacks and visible broken-branch stubs.





Multi-author books and research publications
Quant/science teams and education platforms
Internal documentation portals
…anybody who wants to track and version threads in isolation

Code

Templates
A template is a ready-to-use graft skeleton (project structure, language/tooling, Quarto settings, navigation, dependency strategy). New graft branches start from whatever template lives on the protected template branch.

What makes a good template

Runs immediately with make preview.
Includes the basics:

docs/
_quarto.yaml
Makefile
pyproject.toml (or equivalent for the stack)

Clearly shows:

the primary language/toolchain,
how outputs are rendered,
how notebooks or scripts are handled.




Templates we’d like to see

Python + Jupyter + Polars
R + Quarto + ggplot
JavaScript + Observable + WASM
Book-style chapters vs website-style sections
Research reproducibility templates
Internal documentation templates



How template contributions work

Open a PR to main with your proposed template changes.
Maintainers review for structure, safety, and ergonomics.
Once accepted, maintainers promote it into the protected template branch.
Contributors automatically inherit the updated template when they create new grafts.


Important: No one opens PRs directly into the protected template branch; it remains maintainer-controlled.
Code

Create a new graft
This step can be done by the contributor, or the trunk maintainer.
Clone the repo and create a new graft.
git clone ...
uv run graft-new  --template py-jupyter my-first-graft
This will create a and push a git branch graft/my-first-graft, also updating the grafts.yaml configuration file. The grafts.lock manifest can be updated by running:
uv run trunk-build
You can preview the new graft in the hierarchy using.
uv run quarto preview docs
Each graft template carries its own:
my-first-graft/
├── docs/
│   ├── index.qmd
│   ├── _quarto.yaml
├── .gitignore
├── Makefile
├── README.md

Add content to the graft
The branch is an entirely isolated quartodoc project and knows nothing about the trunk.
The only contract is the following command must succeed using the python dependencies of the trunk.
uv run quarto render docs
Save and push changes to the remote.
git commit -am "added new graft called 'my-first-graft'"
git push
Note: the main trunk does not execute any scripts. This means outputs in notebooks need to be committed to the branch if they should be shown on the main website.

Retire a graft
To see what can be safely removed, run:
uv run graft-list
Then destroy a specific graft branch (local, remote, and config entries) with:
uv run graft-destroy graft/my-first-graft
Code

First Build
uv sync
uv run trunk-build
uv run quarto render docs --no-execute
uv run quarto preview docs
You’ll see the assembled site. If you did not clone all repositories the ‘Grafts from branches’ section will be empty (but that’s fine).

Github Settings
Apply these changes to your github repo settings.

Ensure a gh-pages branch exists.
Ensure the following are set.

Settings -> Actions -> General

Actions permissions -> Allow all actions and reusable workflows
Workflow Permissions Read and write permissions

Settings -> Pages -> Build and deployment

Source -> Deploy from a branch
Branch -> gh-pages


Point Pages at docs/_site.
Render locally or in CI, then push _site to gh-pages.

Publish to Github Pages
This site has github actions configured to work out-of-the-box.

Make a test commit and push from the main branch.
Check the ‘Actions’ page for build logs.
After some time, your site will be published.

Guardrails

Worktrees keep uncommitted work isolated from main.
Navigation updates happen automatically after each build.
Cleaning graft worktrees is safe-guarded; make clean-grafts will refuse to delete dirty worktrees.

Code






API Reference
Project scripts (via uv run) you can advertise to contributors and maintainers.








Command
Purpose
When to use




uv run trunk-build
Build every graft listed in grafts.yaml and refresh navigation.
Regular builds in CI or before publishing.


uv run trunk-lock
Regenerate grafts.lock after successful builds.
After trunk-build to persist the manifest.


uv run graft-new --template <template> <name>
Create a new graft branch from the template.
Onboard a new section/chapter owner.


uv run graft-get <name>
Ensure a worktree exists locally for a graft branch.
When resuming work on an existing graft.


uv run graft-build --branch <name>
Build a single graft branch.
Local iteration on one section.


uv run graft-list
Show graft branches that can safely be destroyed.
Before removing stale grafts.


uv run graft-destroy <branch>
Remove a graft branch locally/remotely and clean config.
When retiring a graft.


uv run graft-cleanup-orphans
Remove .grafts/* directories no longer registered as worktrees.
Repo hygiene if worktrees drift.




Add your own helper scripts here, or link to CI workflows that run these commands.
